info: Comcast is a global media and technology company operating Connectivity & Platforms and Content & Experiences segments. It announced a planned spin‑off of its domestic cable TV networks and related digital assets, targeting completion by the end of 2025 pending board, financing, tax and regulatory approvals. The filing notes Comcast is a large accelerated filer and a well‑known seasoned issuer, with a market value of $150.621 billion for its common stock held by non‑affiliates. As of January 15, 2025, 3,771,578,226 Class A shares and 9,444,375 Class B shares were outstanding.

The company announced a planned spin‑off of its cable‑network assets targeting completion by end‑2025, highlighted ongoing network upgrades delivering up to 10 Gbps residential and 100 Gbps business symmetric speeds, a 2 Gbps residential rollout now covering about 50% of its HFC footprint, low‑income broadband caps at 75 Mbps and 100 Mbps and prepaid 200 Mbps services, and offers device financing up to 48 months.

The Media segment faces intense competition across streaming, broadcast and advertising, with seasonal and cyclical impacts on residential connectivity and ad revenue. Comcast leverages extensive cable network reach (e.g., 66 M households for USA Network) and major broadcast footprints (35 M households via NBC, 71 % of U.S. Hispanic households via Telemundo). Sports rights agreements extend into the 2030s, supporting content offerings. Theme park expansion continues with Epic Universe slated for 2025 and additional parks planned for 2025‑2026.

The company is investing heavily in new theme‑park experiences, including Epic Universe and the Universal Kids Resort slated for 2026 and Universal Horror Unleashed slated for 2025, while continuing to develop attractions, hotels and infrastructure. Theme‑park revenue depends on travel and tourism trends and faces competition from other multi‑park operators. The Media and Studios businesses confront audience fragmentation and seasonal advertising cycles. Regulatory risk is heightened by recent FCC actions – 2023 broadband non‑discrimination rules, a 2024 reclassification of broadband as a Title II service, and a 2025 appellate court reversal returning broadband to Title I – as well as ongoing broadband‑funding initiatives and potential state‑level regulations. The company also participates in broadband‑deployment funding and joint‑venture Xumo, formed in 2022.

The filing highlights extensive privacy and data protection obligations in the U.S. and abroad, FTC oversight, and breach‑notification rules that could force product changes and impact advertising revenue. State and local tax pressures—especially new fees on digital advertising—are noted alongside broader regulatory scrutiny across broadcasting, accessibility, safety and environmental matters. Competitive dynamics are intense across broadband, wireless, video and streaming, with shifting consumer behavior toward DTC services threatening linear TV viewership and advertising dollars, while high‑cost content and sports rights pose cost risks. The company employs roughly 182,000 staff (30% outside the U.S.), runs nine employee resource groups with over 36,000 members in 240 chapters, and granted stock‑based awards to more than 24,000 employees in 2024.

The company faces material risks from reliance on third‑party content rights and programming costs, potential inability to renew or secure favorable contracts for popular and sports programming, heightened competition and piracy impacting revenue, dependence on vendors for hardware, software and satellite capacity, exposure to cyber‑security attacks, weak economic conditions affecting subscriber and advertising demand, execution risks of acquisitions and strategic initiatives, international regulatory, currency and geopolitical risks, and natural disasters that could disrupt operations and damage assets.

The filing highlights material risks from natural disasters, labor disputes, regulatory changes, litigation and cyber threats, notes that Class B stock carries a non‑dilutable 33.33% voting power and a share‑count trigger at 9,444,375 shares, and provides record holder counts for Class A (303,127) and Class B (1) shares as of Jan 15 2025.

Comcast repurchased 212 million Class A shares for $8.6 billion in 2024, raised its quarterly dividend by $0.08 to an annualized $1.24 per share and paid $4.8 billion in dividends, sold its Hulu interest for $8.6 billion, announced a tax‑free Spin‑Co spin‑off targeted for end‑2025, saw residential broadband customers decline while wireless lines grew, maintained $8.3 billion capex in Connectivity, and Peacock revenue rose to $4.9 billion with 36 million subscribers.

Comcast repurchased 212 million shares for $8.6 bn in 2024 (down from 262 million for $11 bn in 2023) and raised its dividend to $1.24 per share, paying $4.8 bn. It received $8.6 bn from the Hulu put‑right sale and plans a tax‑free spin‑off by end‑2025. Consolidated revenue grew modestly to $123.7 bn, with adjusted EBITDA up 1.2% to $38.1 bn. Amortization of acquisition intangibles increased to $2.7 bn. Effective tax rate fell to 15.0% from 26.2%. Connectivity & Platforms revenue was flat at $81.3 bn, with residential revenue slightly down and business services up 4.8%; adjusted EBITDA margin improved to 40.4%.

Management emphasizes growth in higher‑margin connectivity businesses and continued network investment, while noting competitive pressures and the expiration of the Affordable Connectivity Program discount that hurt residential broadband relationships. They expect residential revenue to rise from higher average revenue per customer and growth in wireless and international connectivity, even as video and wireline voice revenues decline. Business Services Connectivity is projected to keep expanding. Cost reductions are evident, especially in programming expenses and total costs.

Residential Connectivity revenues grew modestly with broadband up 2.9% and wireless up 16.6%, while video revenue fell 6.7% and total segment revenue slipped 0.5%, but adjusted EBITDA improved to 27338; Business Services Connectivity revenue rose 4.8% to 9701 with EBITDA increasing to 5500; Content & Experiences saw media revenue jump 11% and total revenue rise 4.4% while studios and theme parks declined, and adjusted EBITDA remained essentially flat at 6735.

Media segment revenue rose 11% to $28.1B in 2024, driven by Olympic-related advertising and distribution gains, while linear TV subscriber decline is offset by Peacock growth to 36M paid subscribers. Costs increased, especially programming and production. Studios segment saw modest revenue decline, with content licensing down 2% and theatrical revenue down 19% due to slate timing and prior work stoppages. Theme parks revenue fell 3.7% as attendance slipped, but pre‑opening costs rose for Epic Universe slated for May 2025. Headquarters and other revenue dropped 22%, reflecting lower overhead. The company expects continued subscriber and rating declines in linear TV, higher content and marketing spend at Peacock, and operational impacts from sporting event timing and labor disruptions.

Expenses decreased in 2024 after higher severance charges in 2023; segment eliminations show modest revenue and cost changes; Corporate and Other revenue rose to $2.933 billion while costs increased; Adjusted EBITDA remained negative; Consolidated Adjusted EBITDA grew modestly to $38.069 billion; Upcoming German Bundesliga broadcast rights will add programming costs; Paris Olympics affected costs; Constant‑currency metrics show slight growth in Connectivity & Platforms revenue and EBITDA.

Comcast posted 2024 total revenue of $71.9 billion (slightly higher on a constant‑currency basis) with adjusted EBITDA around $27 billion, indicating stable profitability. Operating cash flow remained robust at $27.7 billion, while cash, equivalents and debt grew to $7.3 billion and $99.1 billion respectively, and $11.8 billion of revolving‑credit availability was retained. The company repurchased 212 million shares for $8.6 billion under its $15 billion share‑repurchase program, leaving $7.0 billion remaining. Capital expenditures were steady at $8.3 billion, focused on connectivity infrastructure, and debt repayments totaled $3.6 billion alongside new senior‑note issuances adding roughly $6.3 billion of debt.

The company repaid $3.6 billion of debt in 2024, including $1.9 billion of principal notes and multiple 2025/2026 issuances. It maintained an aggressive share‑repurchase strategy, authorizing $15 billion in January 2024, buying back 212 million shares for $8.6 billion and leaving $7.0 billion of authorization unused by year‑end. Quarterly dividends of $0.31 per share resulted in $4.8 billion paid in 2024, with a 6.5% increase approved for 2025. Contractual obligations remain sizable, with $105.1 billion of debt (including $4.9 billion due within 12 months) and $96.2 billion of programming commitments. The debt profile is heavily guaranteed within the Comcast, NBCUniversal and Comcast Cable structure, with $97.1 billion cross‑guaranteed and a weighted‑average interest rate of 3.7% on predominantly fixed‑rate debt. No goodwill or franchise‑right impairments were required in 2024.

The company highlighted material risks that could affect future impairment testing of capitalized film and television content, noting that impairments have not been material to date. It described its content amortization approach and the sensitivity of revenue estimates to theatrical performance and licensing windows. Interest rate risk is managed through derivatives, which increased consolidated interest expense by $49 million in 2024 after decreasing it in prior years. Fixed‑rate debt is primarily in the $4.9‑$7.0 billion range for 2025‑2028, with total debt of $105.1 billion and a fair‑value estimate of $89.8 billion. Fixed‑to‑variable swap notional amounts total $2.5 billion (estimated fair value –$0.2 billion). Average pay and receive rates on swaps range from 6.3%‑6.8% and 3.3%‑4.2% respectively. Foreign‑exchange exposure analysis indicated a hypothetical 10% currency shift would not materially affect 2024 net income, and no collateral was required for derivative counterparties.

The company disclosed exposure to foreign‑exchange risk from foreign operations and related hedges, noting that a hypothetical 10% currency shift would not materially affect 2024 net income. It manages derivative counterparty risk through diversification and credit monitoring, and reported no collateral was required or held as of Dec 31, 2024 and 2023. Management affirmed effective internal control over financial reporting, and auditors issued an unqualified opinion on the financial statements and controls. Critical audit focus was on revenue recognition for bundled residential and platform services.

Comcast reported modest revenue growth to $123.7 billion in 2024 with operating income remaining stable and net income attributable to shareholders increasing to $16.2 billion. Goodwill stayed high at $58 billion, including $20 billion in the Media unit, with no impairment recorded. A corporate reorganization produced a $9.1 billion capital loss and a $1.9 billion tax refund benefit. Margins were supported by steady programming, marketing and administrative costs, while basic EPS rose to $4.17.

Operating cash flow remained strong at 27.7 B in 2024, supporting 12.2 B of capital expenditures, 9.1 B of share repurchases and 4.8 B of dividends. Net income rose to 15.9 B, and cash balances grew to 7.3 B. Total assets and equity modestly increased, while goodwill impairments were absent.

The 2024 equity statement shows total equity of $86.0B, up from $83.2B in 2023, driven by net income of $16.2B and retained earnings increase; dividends per share rose to $1.24. The company announced a planned spin‑off of cable networks into a new public entity (SpinCo) targeted for completion by end‑2025.

2024 total consolidated revenue rose to $123.7 billion from $121.6 billion in 2023, driven by higher Media and Business Services Connectivity revenues, while Residential Connectivity, Studios and Theme Parks saw modest declines. Segment Adjusted EBITDA increased to $40.3 billion, led by Residential and Business Services segments; Theme Parks EBITDA fell. Intersegment revenue remained roughly flat. Investment income turned negative, and income before taxes decreased to $18.7 billion from $20.5 billion.

Comcast reported total consolidated revenue of $123.7B in 2024, up from $121.4B in 2022, driven by growth in Residential Connectivity & Platforms and Media segments; Adjusted EBITDA reached $38.4B in 2024. Intersegment revenue of $8.8B and eliminations of $9.0B affected consolidated results. U.S. customers contributed the majority of revenue (~$96B), with the United Kingdom and other regions providing additional $27B. Contracts represent less than 10% of future Residential Connectivity & Platforms revenue, and equipment installment plans offer interest‑free financing over up to 48 months for international customers.

Comcast details its revenue recognition across residential, business, media, studios and theme park segments, noting that contract‑based revenue represents less than 10% of residential connectivity revenue and about half of business services revenue, with most deferred within 2 years. Advertising is recorded net of agency commissions and fees are passed through. Credit risk is managed via an allowance that increased to $738 million in 2024, with provisions of $747 million and write‑offs of $707 million. Receivables net $13.7 billion (2024) and non‑current deferred revenue $665 million. Production tax incentives reduced capitalized film costs by $455 million and overall programming and production expenses by $652 million in 2024.

Production tax incentives reduced owned film and TV capitalized costs by $455M (2024) and $418M (2023) and cut programming costs, while creating $2.2B and $1.9B receivables. Future amortization schedules show significant expense for owned and licensed content through 2025‑2027, and the company has $2.8B of future licensed‑content commitments. Current accrued participation liabilities are $1.44B (2024) and $1.67B (2023). Income before taxes remained strong domestically but foreign results were negative; total pre‑tax income was $18.7B (2024) versus $20.5B (2023). Income tax expense fell to $2.80B in 2024 driven by lower current tax and a $1.92B internal reorganization charge. Net deferred tax liability stands at $25.1B.

Valuation allowance rose to $4.5bn in 2024, driven by higher foreign net operating loss carryforwards of $11.8bn. A corporate reorganization produced a $9.1bn federal net capital loss and a $1.9bn tax refund, while net current federal tax receivable reached $2.0bn. Gross unrecognized tax benefits increased to $2.865bn, which could affect the effective tax rate if recognized. Total debt grew to $99.1bn (non‑current $94.2bn) with $4.9bn current portion and a fair value of $89.8bn. The company secured a new $11.8bn revolving credit facility (up to $14.8bn) with no borrowings and holds $288m of standby letters of credit. Derivative gains were $0.1bn and net investment hedge effects added $0.9bn to other comprehensive income. Debt maturities through 2029 total $30.1bn with $77.7bn beyond 2029.

Net investment hedges yielded modest gains in 2024, while overall investment income was volatile with a loss in 2024 and a gain in 2023. Equity method investments declined slightly, and cash distributions from those investments rose to $297 million in 2024. Atairos commitments were trimmed, leaving $1.4 billion of unfunded capital as of year‑end, with cash contributions falling to $73 million in 2024 and the investment balance at $5.1 billion. The Hulu sale generated $8.6 billion cash in 2023, but the recorded Hulu investment remains low ($883 million in 2024). Universal Beijing Resort debt remains high (~$3.4 billion) with assets of $7.3 billion. Property and equipment net rose to $62.5 billion, and short‑term instrument activity showed $702 million of proceeds in 2024.

Property and equipment rose to $62.5 billion in 2024 from $59.7 billion in 2023, led by U.S. assets increasing to $52.6 billion. Goodwill remains roughly $66‑$68 billion, with a prior $8.1 billion Sky goodwill impairment recorded in 2022. Management highlights ongoing asset recoverability reviews and notes a remote risk that franchise terminations could trigger significant restoration costs.

In 2022 Comcast recorded a $8.1 billion goodwill impairment in its Sky unit and a $485 million intangible‑asset impairment due to macro‑economic pressures, while indefinite‑lifed franchise rights remain valued at $59.4 billion and total finite‑lifed intangibles at $56.8 billion with amortization slated at $3.0 billion in 2025 tapering to $0.5 billion by 2029; deferred compensation obligations rose to $4.8 billion in 2024 with $370 million interest expense, pension costs are about $660 million annually, share‑based compensation expense exceeds $1 billion each year, and comprehensive income reflects translation losses of $2.5 billion in 2024.

Share-based compensation expense rose to $1.069 billion in 2024 with a $222 million tax benefit; unrecognized pretax compensation of $2.1 billion remains. Interest cash payments were $3.657 billion and tax cash payments $7.096 billion, including $1.7 billion of tax credit purchases. The company accrued $2.8 billion of property, plant and intangible acquisitions and recorded a $1.2 billion dividend liability. Cash and equivalents totaled $7.322 billion with restricted cash $55 million. Operating lease expense stayed at $1.2 billion, future lease commitments total $9.84 billion (liability $6.319 billion). A contractual obligation carries $1.1 billion on the books, valued at $1.8 billion. Governance updates include amended bylaws and CEO Roberts holding ~33.33% voting power.

Brian L. Roberts serves as Chairman, President and CEO with sole voting power of roughly 33.33% of the combined voting power of Comcast’s two classes of common stock. The executive team includes long‑tenured leaders such as Michael J. Cavanagh (President since Oct 2022, former Carlyle and JPMorgan executive), Jason S. Armstrong (CFO since Jan 2023, former Goldman Sachs executive), Jennifer Khoury (Chief Communications Officer since Feb 2020 with prior Comcast and AT&T roles), Daniel C. Murdock (Executive VP and CAO since Mar 2020, former SEC deputy chief accountant), and Thomas J. Reid (Chief Legal Officer and Secretary since Apr 2019, former law firm chair and Morgan Stanley managing director). Executive compensation details are referenced to the 2025 Proxy Statement.

The filing lists numerous exhibit references covering supplemental indentures, credit agreements, and various employee compensation and stock plans, but provides no substantive operational or financial updates.

The filing lists numerous exhibits, including employment agreements, stock option and incentive plan summaries, shareholder agreements, and certifications, and provides the CEO's signature on the report.
